writingDetail.html:
Hi everyone, this is Sam Black with Drafting Archetypes, and today I'm going to be discussing red-black in Duskmourne. As always, the notes are available to follow along at patreon.com/draftingarchetypes. Red-black is the second least drafted color pair, so it's not drafted very much, but it is the fourth most successful. So it performs pretty well, but people don't draft it very much, which is interesting to me because I think there's like a lot of support and it's high synergy. It's not one of those archetypes where there's like a suggested theme that doesn't work.

The support's there, the power level's there, so it's a little bit surprising that it's not drafted so much. I think the explanation is that it wants cards that most other decks don't want, so it's hard to pivot into or out of, and that makes it difficult to commit to early, because if the cards end up not being there, then you have a bunch of cards that you can't really use anywhere else. And so I think there's like correctly a pressure to not put yourself in this space, and then once you see that it's open, it's hard to move into it because the cards that you have aren't likely to play well with the cards that you'd like want for this archetype.

So you kind of have to just kind of like move in pretty early on some kind of reasonably good card for it and hope that it's there. The good news is that it usually is, because it's so rarely drafted and there is a lot of support for it and the cards that you want, very few other people want basically any of them. So I think it's good to draft but not safe to draft. In general, I'm not a believer in like, sometimes people ask questions like, "Okay, so it's like the second draft in a Grand Prix, you need the 3/0 to top eight, is there a deck that you draft specifically to 3/0?" I generally feel like you just draft.

Like you take the good cards and you know, you don't do something different based on like needing a 3/0 or needing a 2/1. But I could see an argument that this deck more than most kind of fits in that space where you have a pretty good expectation that it's going to work, since it's not very drafted, all the stuff I've said. But if someone else is in it or if the cards just aren't there, you might be in a lot of trouble because it's hard to pivot out of. So do with that what you will in terms of what it says about how often you should or shouldn't draft it. So that's kind of its positioning. Well, before I get into the best comments on comments, let me talk about its strategic positioning,

what the deck is trying to do and how it fits into the format. So, red-black has this like sacrifice theme, which means that you want to draft cheap cards that give you value when you sacrifice them or they die. Things like Clockwork Percussionist and Inocuous Rat. Clockwork Percussionist is the red 1/1 haste artifact creature that when it dies, like, so it's the top card of your library, you could play it until the end of your next turn. And Inocuous Rat is the one in a black 1/1 that when it dies, you manifest the top card of your library. So you want that kind of card to support the things that you want you to sacrifice something.

That kind of card is good in the deck because it has a lot of synergy and it's like pretty reasonable at attacking early, but it's not good to draw in the late game because it's a low impact card. Given that you want like a bunch of cheap creatures to sacrifice to fuel your stuff, you're structurally in the "creatures then removal spells rather than removal spells then creatures" kind of space, which ballpark means that you're an aggressive deck rather than a controlling deck. A thing that I've started talking about somewhat frequently more recently is this idea that aggressive decks play creatures then removal spells. So you get on board, kill your opponent's blockers and attack. Whereas controlled decks are more likely to play removal spells. So you don't fall behind early, you answer your opponent's evasive threats.

You don't want to be in a spot where your opponent has a threat, you play creature, they kill it and they hit you. You'd rather be in a spot where they play a creature, you kill it. And then if they have a removal spell, they fail to apply more pressure. And then you're more likely to have expensive creatures that turn the game around or go over the top or whatever. So your removal spells then creatures then control decks, creatures then removal spells and aggressive decks. So Red/Black wants a bunch of cheap creatures and some of its removal spells like Final Vengeance, the Bone Splinters variant in this set, Black Sorcery Sack creature or Enchantment Exile Tiger creature needs you to have a creature,

although this one can use enchantments, but for the most part, once you have a creature in play early so that you can cast it. So you kind of have to be creatures then removal. In that way, like you're kind of naturally set up to be an aggressive deck just because you're going to have creatures in play and then you're going to have these removal spells and you're going to want to kill your opponent's blockers so the creatures that you have in play are doing something. Also, when you look at the larger format positioning, blue in this format is pretty good and has a lot of strong card advantage. Like the fact that both Glimmer Burst and Meat Locker are commons that are pretty good means that if you're like a Red/Black deck that's trying to play like a hard Attrition plan rather than an aggressive plan, the blue deck is going to out card advantage your like Nickel and Dime type leftover object card advantage that you get out of Red/Black, so you don't really want to be going into a late game with them.

And you don't really want to be going into a late game with most decks because you have all these really low impact cards in your deck. So to avoid the spot where like you're top decking but a lot of your cards don't matter and your opponent's going to be drawing like way more significant cards or the spot where you're playing an Attrition game against blue decks that are drawing a lot more cards than you, you really need your like cheap creatures to be pushing damage. The synergies are all real and important. The fact that you can like get card advantage out of your removal spells matters, but all of this stuff needs to be about mounting pressure and pushing damage and getting toward the end of the game. So you do want the like grindy synergy stuff, you just need that to be the backdrop for an aggressive start and to focus on you know the thing that you're accomplishing with all this stuff is getting attacks in. So that's kind of what I think like Red/Black needs to be up to. So this is a kind of, this is a pretty common dynamic for Red/Black right?

Red/Black has a lot of removal spells in general and you know you usually want like some creatures that are attacking while you play removal spells, it's usually pretty aggressive. However, there is the potential sometimes to play Red/Black control Attrition strategies where you know you have like some big creatures and some card advantage, some grindy elements and a bunch of removal and you end up playing a control game and this makes more sense the more like you know dragons you have like random creatures that like like bombs you know your typical bombs and removal control deck in limited. The thing is even at Rare and Mythic there are very few Red or Black cards in Dustmourne that are really strong and make you want to play that kind of game. This isn't a set where there are a bunch of dragons, there is the room that makes a demon and then there are the two overlords at Mythic and you could splash like Vel'Gavath's Onslaught, the Manifest X card, but most of the like Red and Black Rare creatures are just like cheap aggressive cards.

So it's very rare that you're going to be in a spot where you you know you're in Red/Black but it's because of some rare that makes you comfortable playing a long game. Like this isn't a set that really has that kind of element so you're basically always going to be interested in damaging your opponent as like a serious part of your game plan. That's not to say that any of the synergy stuff is like fake or misleading, it's just that this is something you need to be thinking about when you're drafting and building your deck and playing your games. Like you need to have creatures and you care more about those creatures having power than you care about most of the other elements of the creatures because you're going to be killing a lot of your opponent's blockers. So you just want to be getting in. So a card like Most Valuable Slayer, the 4 mana 2/4 that gives a creature +1/+0 in first strike isn't very good here because that's good for like getting your creatures past blockers but in Red/Black it doesn't have a good like power to mana ratio and you're mostly just like killing the things that would block anyway. So that's not the kind of creature you're looking for. You're looking for something like say Piggy Bank,

1/3/2 dies into a treasure just because it has 3 power and 2 toughness for 2 mana. And so I said you mostly want power but also toughness does matter somewhat. Specifically if your creature has 1 toughness and doesn't have an ability that like triggers when it dies then you might have a problem where your opponent makes tokens and you really don't have to use your removal spells on their tokens and then you can't keep attacking. So 3/2 is a pretty good stat line but you know 2/2s work. Hand that feeds the 1/2/2 that gets +2/+0 and menace if you have delirium works pretty well if your deck is set up to get delirium. But it's I don't know that it's all that important which creatures you have as long as you know you have like some 1 and 2 mana creatures that you know that you need to be like planning to attack with and you don't just like have your early game shouldn't be just all removal spells right like you can play like winter's intervention and stuff I think that's the name of the one in a black dl2 game too but that's not a good fit for this deck. You shouldn't be worried about gaining life you have more effective removal spells for attacking than that. You have enough removal spells that you really shouldn't need to like go there. Leave that for like a blue black deck or whatever and take just like a 2 mana creature or something instead. So understanding that that's what we're trying to do looking at the top performing commons/noncommons.

The top performing common in red black is glimmerlight. This isn't terribly surprising it's one of the best performing commons in the set and it works well with having like a bunch of random little disposable creatures makes all of your percussionists and rats and manifests able to attack more reliably deals with the problem of your opponent having 1/1s and that invalidating some of your attacks. It's two objects in one card for two mana so it works well with sacrificing and stuff. Very very good fit here. I think it's underrated in red black. I think looking at how frequently and when cards are drafted relative to their win rate glimmerlight's the only thing that stands out is like this isn't in as many red and black decks as it should be and it doesn't like go super early relative to some of the cards that people are putting in their red and black decks. So I think glimmerlight is important, underrated, and despite you know being very successful and is definitely card you should be looking for. Final Vengeance, the removal spell that I talked about earlier, Clockwork Percussionist,

the 1/1 haste for one that I talked about earlier, Glassworks, the room that does 4 damage to a creature and then for 5 mana becomes an enchantment that does 1 to your opponent every turn. This is you know just good removal spell that gives you an object that you can sacrifice and also some reach, you know ways to push damage in the late game to stop your opponent from kind of stabilizing and turning the corner. Inocuous Rat, the 2 mana 1/1 that dies into a manifest. Scorching Dragonfire, one in red deal 3 exile and Fear of Lost Teeth, the black 1/1 that deals 1 to any target in game's life when it dies, enchantment creature. So just like little creatures that give you value and removal spells are the best performing commons. Top Uncommons, Razorcan Hoardcaller,

the 5 mana 4/4 that makes a 1/1 whenever you attack is the top performer, followed by Nowhere to Run, that's the black enchantment that -3/-3 and ignores ward and hexproof and stuff. Again just removal spell that gives you an object. Disturbing Murph, the red/black uncommon that lets you sacrifice a thing to draw to and manifests when it dies. Vengeful Possession, the Threaten. Piggy Bank, the 3/2. Betrayer's Bargain, the 2 mana sacrifice a thing or pay 2 extra mana to deal 5 in exile and Fear of Burning Alive,

the 6 mana 4/4 that deals 4 and if you have Delirium whenever you - it deals 4 to an opponent and if you have Delirium when you deal damage to an opponent it also deals damage to creatures. So you know pretty typical good uncommons but still very much in the like we're looking for sacrifice synergies space. Disturbing Murph is very significant, it's a really good card and you know suggests very much this like attrition plan where you're sacrificing something to draw cards but then you sacrifice it for more value which means you need more synergy but the value you're getting is just another creature. It's a good card that like gives you more fuel to let you keep going but it doesn't change the dynamic that I've been discussing. Like I've seen a lot of good red/black decks have like 3 copies of Disturbing Murph because sacrificing Disturbing Murph to Disturbing Murph is awesome because you you know get your manifest which you want to get as soon as possible and you you know get to draw the two cards from the next one. And you know this lets you kind of like chain value and snowball a bit but it's all you know cheap and like in line with attacking. So yeah it plays well in the game plan rather than really changing the game plan. The last thing I want to touch on is well sorry one time I guess one more quick note about specific cards. Murder, one black black destroy target creature, Clemon instant.

Totally reasonable card to play but you know again looking at when it's taken, how often it's played compared to its win rate suggests that it's probably appreciably overrated. It's a fine card but nothing special. The rate's just not that good. You'd rather have the like more specifically synergistic removal spells which again it's not to say that like if you draft murder you shouldn't play it or that you should avoid drafting it but you might want to take a good creature over it and find like a different removal spell later on. So the other note, this deck doesn't really want to splash. Like you're a high synergy, somewhat color intensive, low curve aggro deck. You can often get away with playing fewer than 17 lands. The only real exceptions are Vaugavath's Onslaught,

the XX green manifest X rare, and the Swarmweaver, the two black green creature that makes two insects and gives them +1/+1 and Deathhatch if you have Delirium. Those are like very very strong and pretty easily splashable and work well enough with what you're doing but for the most part you really want to stick to just like straight red black here. This is always what I'm going to tell you with aggressive archetypes. So that covers what I have to say about this. So I'm going to move on to questions from chat. So if anyone has any questions please don't hesitate to send them to Twitch chat and I will get to them shortly. In the meantime I want to thank the newest Patreon at patreon.com/draftingarchetypes so Jamie thank you very much for the support, really appreciate it. If anyone else is interested in supporting the program be sure to check out patreon.com/draftingarchetypes.

First question, when you say "disturbing mirth for more value" what kind of value do you mean? When you say you sacrifice disturbing mirth for more value, I mean like the text of disturbing mirth right like it does two things. It lets you sacrifice a thing to draw two cards and then when you sacrifice it you manifest. So the first value you get out of it is when you cast it you sacrifice something to draw two cards and then when you sacrifice it you get more value and you trigger the second ability and you get another creature. So the value that I mean is manifesting. Can you talk about the difference between red black good cards deck versus red black sac synergy options? Interesting framing, I hadn't strongly considered that there could be a red black deck that's not really doing the sac synergy stuff because like so the issue is that the black cards aren't that good right like the the red and black gold cards are sac synergy cards and the strong red cards in like other decks aren't necessarily strong in red black and like I don't know that I believe in a red black good cards deck that's like a distinct thing from red black sac synergy deck I guess is my answer.

Like I could imagine that you can have more or less of the sac synergy stuff but it just seems hard for me to like imagine exactly how a draft is going such that you don't have any of the sac synergy stuff and you're supposed to be in red black given that like there's so many of the cards that do that thing and they go so late and there's not really like a different thing to be doing because the uncommons want to do that and the commons that like go late and make sense do that. I'm not saying it's not possible to have a draft where you just happen to not see any of the sac synergy stuff and you just like get like a large number of like I don't know good uncommons and rooms and stuff but I suspect that almost every red black deck is meaningfully doing the sacrifice thing. What about the green black spider? I assume we're talking about the two drop uncommon. That doesn't seem like a card that I'd really want to splash in red black. Like it's very good. I think that splashing the two mana uncommons can be pretty good especially with like manifest stuff. I think it would be a good card to play if you were already splashing green for onslaught or swarmweaver but I don't think I want to like mess up my mana for an off color two drop in a red black deck. How does fear of lost teeth earn its spot in the deck? It seems too weak to me but I see good players including it in their decks.

I mean just the fact that it does a damage to any target when it dies and you get to have it die on command and there are like a decent number of like one toughness creatures around and it's also like you're you're not like enchantment creature for delirium is pretty nice and just like aggressive one mana creature is pretty nice and it also like can attack into tutus right like if your opponent manifests and you have that you can attack and if they block they trade so it's like a little bit better at pushing damage than it might look. Yeah it's a acceptable one mana spell to sacrifice to disturbing mirth which is certainly something you can be looking for. Surprised irreverent gremlin didn't come up for a good uncommon for this space considering. So I mean irreverent gremlin's good. I believe it's like literally the next best uncommon stats wise after fear of running alive. It's just I stopped listing cards at some point to avoid an impossibly long list and irreverent gremlin was the exact cutoff but it's it's a very good card it should be in your decks it's you know like better than fear of lost teeth I just didn't mention it because you know the bar for uncommon is a little higher than bar for commons to be worth mentioning. Some ratio or number of cards that you want of good things to sac versus things that cards that sac things. I mean conceptually you want more good things to sacrifice than cards that sacrifice things right because like you want more of the like prerequisite whereas if you have like more of the stuff that needs to sacrifice then you're gonna like strand some of it or it's gonna be bad because you're gonna have to sacrifice something that's not good to sacrifice. As to like exact number of each I don't have one in mind it's not something that I've like thought about and I haven't like drafted this enough to have like a map for it or anything. Basically I think you know you just want to like it's not that hard to have like most of your cards give you a good thing to sacrifice in one way or another with like clockwork percussionist and glimmer light and rat and every room and you know nowhere to run type stuff disturbing mirth like it's very easy in these colors to have stuff that's good to sacrifice so broadly I'm just like take stuff that's in one bucket or the other and it'll probably work out.

That's the thing about how I think that this archetype is just very deeply supported. Put of a splash in the red white uncommon make three gremlins. It's a good card it fits well in the strategy. Again it's not how I want to be spending my picks like taking that and taking the lands to support it and then having the like awkward lands but you know I could see taking that like pivoting into red black after having that taking that early when I might pivot out of red black ending up with it in my pool looking for some like white lands that I happen to get late just in case it comes together and I want to splash it and if I get like you know three to four white dual lands or something then maybe I put it in. I don't think it's something that you should prioritize but I could see it coming together. Do you think there's a Jund delirium deck and if so how does this deck relate to it? Yes I do and I think the decks are very different but they involve some overlapping pieces I think that the Jund delirium deck for it can use Disturbing Mirth and likes potentially stuff like Inocuous Rat and Fear of Lost Heath and Clockwork Percussionist because all of those are pretty good at putting multiple types in the graveyard and if you have those things with some sacrifice synergies then you can pretty easily get like three types in the graveyard very quickly while getting some like value out of that stuff.

I think Gendelirium is more in the attrition space and typically less aggressive,

but I think it's like solidly mid-range.

you are still generally pressuring your opponent and you do, like,
